answer.text:
I'm sure a rare example of someone with seemingly boundless energy is my grandfather. It seems his motto is, "Life's too short to be idle."

Now in his late 70s and retired, he could sleep late, spend more time in bed, read books, or watch TV. But instead, he's always on the go, despite his age. He wakes up with the sun and starts his day with morning exercises outdoors, regardless of the weather or season. Then he gets to work on chores like washing and cleaning. Since my grandmother passed away 20 years ago, he's done all the housework himself. He also works in the yard, the orchard, and his vegetable garden. Yet, he never seems to feel tired. At least, he never says he's tired. In fact, the more he does, the more energized he seems to get. It's incredible. I'm just 30, and I'm nowhere near as active as him. At the end of the day, I can't wait to get home and collapse on the couch. My grandfather, on the other hand, is always up for an evening stroll. I rely on extra-large coffees to get through the day, but he never relies on caffeine. He believes the most powerful source of energy comes from within.

When people ask him how he stays so energized, he always says there are three keys to living a vibrant life. First, he says his energy levels are directly tied to how refreshed he feels each morning. He never sacrifices sleep, especially for TV, and he eats well. Second, he surrounds himself with the right people - those who are passionate about life, knowledge, and work - and avoids people who constantly complain. Finally, he believes in doing something meaningful with his time. He spreads enthusiasm to everyone around him, and his energy is infectious. I can't help admiring him and wish there were more people like him.

answer.text:
My grandfather was a doctor. He had been working at a regional hospital for more than 50 years until he retired. He started his career as a doctor's assistant, and later became a doctor. He examined, diagnosed and treated patients. He literally worked day and night. I think it was hard. Very hard. But I'm sure that he did exactly what he was born to do, and he wouldn't have changed his job for all the world. For him, it wasn't just a job, it was his calling.

My grandfather's work occupied all his time. He never had a second job. It was just impossible as he had no time for that. If he had had a second job, he would have died of fatigue. Sometimes I doubted my grandfather was a human being. He didn't have hobbies. He didn't spend time with friends. He even missed most family gatherings. You know, it's not fun at all. He was always tired, and his eyes were always red because of endless sleepless nights. When he wasn't on duty, he was reading different books and reviewing medical records of his patients.

In my opinion, it is a very rewarding job. But I wouldn't like to do anything like that because it's really stressful, especially when you understand that you cannot help some patient. Plus, shift work is not my thing. I can't imagine myself working night shifts. What's more, I don't want to sacrifice everything for work.

Since childhood I've been interested in Astronomy. Astrophysics, to be precise. This is the branch of Astronomy that studies the physics of stellar phenomena and other objects in space. Though I have to admit that I'm not a science-obsessed person. I mean, if I come across an interesting article, I read it with pleasure. If I don’t, I don’t deliberately search for this information, nor do I do it regularly. From time to time I watch documentaries, read articles on the Internet, get some new information from friends. But as I've said before, I don't do it very often.

I don’t really remember what got me into space and all that stuff. It feels like I’ve been interested in it for as long as I can remember.. For example, by the time I was five, I already recall being interested in Astronomy.. I think I got started on the science track when I started reading a lot of science fiction books and encyclopedias as a child. Also, my parents read me books on planets and my father told me many interesting facts about our solar system. My interest to this topic was fueled several years ago after watching Interstellar, a wonderful science fiction movie which made me think about black holes, wormholes, space time, dark matter, time dilation for several weeks. I was more than impressed.

The main reason why I like Astrophysics is that everything mysterious captivates me. I really want to understand how everything that exists works, to have a better understanding of the universe we live in and understand how the cosmos influences different processes on our planet.

In my experience, things go wrong when I least expect it. Last winter, I had an overnight bus journey from Big City to Cool City.

When I found out I needed to make this trip, train tickets were already sold out, and buying a plane ticket was out of the question. It was way too expensive. So, taking the bus was my only option at the time.

I hate travelling long distances by bus, especially at night, mostly because I can't sleep sitting up. This was exactly the case. Since I couldn't sleep, I stared out of the window. It was almost dawn, so I could barely see anything, but it was still better than staring at the back of the seat in front of me.

Suddenly I heard a dull thud, and a few minutes later, the bus stopped. The driver got off to check, but he didn’t come back for half an hour.

At first, everything seemed ok. All the passengers were sleeping and had no idea something was wrong. If I had been able to sleep, I probably wouldn’t have noticed anything either. But unfortunately, I wasn’t as lucky as the others.

Several hours later everyone woke up and realized that we were stuck in the middle of nowhere. The worst part? There was no toilet - not even trees or bushes in sight. Just an endless field. For people like me, who are used to modern conveniences, it was a nightmare.

As time went on, people grew angrier by the hour. Some passengers even lost their temper and started yelling at the driver, even though it wasn’t his fault. He was doing everything he could to fix the problem, but it wasn’t easy.

We ended up spending five or six hours on the side of the highway before we could finally continue the journey.. But I wasn't really happy because I missed a very important meeting.

Last Sunday, I went to the village to visit my grandparents. During the pandemic, I didn’t visit them at all because I was afraid to infect them. I missed them very much. My grandpa even said he was more afraid to die of loneliness than of coronavirus. So since the pandemic, I’ve been visiting them more often to make up for the time we lost even though it takes me 5 hours to get there.

My grandparents live in a quiet and beautiful place by the river. They have a cozy house with a big garden. There are lots of flowers, and sometimes orchids bloom too. You know, being there is like travelling back in time. Everything reminds me of my carefree childhood: my toys, old CDs, my bicycle. It feels like you step into another world. All the walls are still covered with old wallpaper. My grandmother doesn’t allow us to remove it, and she refuses to get their house refurbished because she wants to keep all their memories alive. She says they both love their 50-year-old chairs and armchairs, their old wooden table in the kitchen, paintings, clay pots, old pictures, and lots of things they bought when they were young.

You know, I think she’s right. There’s something special about this old house. It’s a magical place, and I really love spending time there. When I visit, I enjoy going fishing and exploring the countryside during the day. In the evenings, I watch the sunset from the backyard. I drink hot tea and eat cinnamon buns. My grandmother always bakes them when I come because she knows how much I love them. If I didn't have so much on my plate and if the trip didn't take so long, I would visit them more often.

About six months ago, I read this book called The Miracle Morning. It really inspired me to try waking up at 5 a.m.

At first, it was insanely hard because I was the type of person who would stay in bed as long as possible, hitting snooze like five times. But little by little, it got easier. Finally, I got used to waking up early. And now I wake up at 5 a.m. without any struggle.

Honestly, it’s been a game-changer for me. Before, I used to wake up already feeling tired, like I’d been carrying heavy loads all night. I’d feel drained all day long. I used to drink three cups of coffee just to function. And even that didn’t always help. I have no idea how it works, but now I feel full of energy.

This change has made me so much more productive, both at work and at home. Plus, I finally have time for myself. In the mornings, while everyone else is still asleep, I read, do yoga, meditate, and plan my day. Sometimes, I watch interesting YouTube videos or listen to podcasts. So I can see how much my life has improved because of this simple habit.

I usually ask for an exchange if there’s something wrong with my purchase. I only return things when the product can’t be fixed or exchanged, or if it didn’t meet my expectations. That’s exactly what happened with a pair of sneakers I bought a few weeks ago. I bought them because I saw a big discount online and thought, ‘Wow, such a great deal!’ I placed the order right away, without second-guessing. When I tried them on at home, they seemed perfect. They looked amazing and felt fine. I couldn’t wait to wear them out. So I decided to take them for a walk the very next day.

When I started walking, I felt something was off, but at that point, I couldn't figure out what exactly was wrong. The next day, I gave them another shot. I was hoping they’d get better with time. But they didn’t. This time, it hurt everywhere, and my left foot was literally one big blister. The sneakers were beautiful and high-quality, but I knew I’d never wear them again. So I had no choice but to return them.

Thank God, the store had a simple return policy. I just filled out a form online, packed the sneakers back into the box, and dropped them off at the nearest courier service. Within a week, I got my refund.

This mishap happened to me a long time ago, but I still remember it like it was yesterday. My boss invited me to lunch to discuss my long-term career plans. I had even heard through the grapevine that he was going to offer me a new position and a bigger project.

One day, when I was supposed to be at the café, I was in the office working as if everything was normal. It wasn’t until I saw my boss’s name on my phone screen that I remembered our meeting.

You know, I was absolutely shocked. I had a panic attack, and I just wanted the ground to open up and swallow me. I couldn’t believe I had completely forgotten about it. It just slipped my mind.

I realized how awful the situation was. My boss had rearranged his busy schedule to meet me, and I hadn’t even shown up. I felt deeply ashamed of what had happened, and I didn’t have a single excuse. I felt so guilty knowing he had wasted his valuable time waiting for me instead of focusing on something important. I was terrified that he might think I didn’t value the opportunity or respect his time.

On top of that, I was in shock because nothing like this had ever happened to me before, and I didn’t know how to handle it. Of course, I apologized a hundred times, but it didn’t make me feel any better. I knew he had wasted his precious time because of me, and I couldn’t forgive myself for it.

So, at my work, there's this one rule that everyone knows about, and it's all about being on time. It's a pretty simple rule, really. But it's super important for keeping things running smoothly. I mean we work in a busy office where we have to coordinate a lot of tasks and projects. If someone is late, it can mess up the whole schedule. Meetings get delayed, deadlines get pushed back, and it can be a real headache for everyone. So if it weren't for this rule, we would have a really hard time getting work done. Literally.

So, I totally get why this rule is in place, and I actually think it's a good one. It helps us stay organized and make sure we're all on the same page. Plus, it shows respect for our colleagues and the company because we're valuing everyone's time.

But here's the thing: not everyone followed this rule. There were a few coworkers who were constantly late, and it was frustrating. It was not fair to the rest of us who made an effort to be on time, and it often created tension in the office.

Now, if someone does break this rule and is late without a good reason, there are consequences. Usually, our boss will have a chat with them and remind them of the importance of being punctual. If it keeps happening, they might get a formal warning. And if it continues after that, well, they could even lose their job.

So, while the rule about being on time might seem strict, I think it's necessary to keep things running smoothly and maintain a respectful work environment. And personally, I'm all for it because it makes my workday a lot less stressful.

In my school, there's this really long list of rules we have to follow. Most of them are there to make sure the school is safe and orderly and that we students behave ourselves. But some of these rules are just way too strict. Like, we have to wear a uniform. Girls wear a shirt, a knee-length woolen skirt, socks or tights, and shoes. Boys wear a shirt and trousers. And we can only buy our uniforms from one specific place to make sure we all look exactly the same. No other options are allowed. Then there's the whole thing about how we look. Piercings are not allowed. No jewelry, no makeup, and we can't even have our hair dyed. If you have long hair, it has to be tied back all the time.

Now, don't get me wrong, I get that wearing a uniform is practical and it helps keep distractions in check. When everyone dresses the same way, it's easier to focus on schoolwork instead of what people are wearing. And no one gets teased for not following fashion trends, which is nice.

But honestly, at my school, these rules are just over the top. I mean, I get it if we came to school in ripped jeans, that's not cool. But why the heck should plain blue jeans with no fancy stuff be a problem. Shirts have to be tucked in, which is fine. It makes us look neat. But if your socks aren't pulled up or your shoes' heel straps aren't perfect, you can be sent home or given a talking to. And if you dare to wear even tiny earrings, they make you take them out. You can't even go back to class until your parents meet with the principal or teacher. That's insane. And for the boys, if they wear the wrong kind of shoes or trousers, they can get detention or even suspended for one to ten days. Thank God, we don't have physical punishment.

Honestly, without the uniform policy, I think we'd be showing up in all sort of outfits like sweaters, short skirts, hoodies, you name it. Most of us would probably have tattoos and piercings galore. It'd be a total mess. But the extreme rules we have in our school aren't much better.

answer.text:
A few years ago, I made a decision that completely changed my life. I had been working at the same company for nearly 5 years. It was a stable job with a steady income, but deep down I knew I wasn't happy. I felt like I was stuck in a rut and there were no opportunities to grow professionally or be promoted. I had always dreamed of starting my own business, but the idea of leaving my stable job and taking such a big risk was terrifying. However, as time went on, I became more and more unhappy with my current situation. I began to realize that if I didn't make a change soon, I might regret it for the rest of my life.

I started doing research, talking to other entrepreneurs, and developing a business plan. I also spoke to my friends and family about my decision and sought their support.

It wasn't an easy decision to leave my stable job, but I knew it was the right one. I was nervous about the financial risk and the potential for failure, but I also felt excited about the prospect of pursuing my dream and creating something that was truly my own.

It's been a few years since I started my business, and it hasn't always been easy. There have been many ups and downs, but I have never regretted my decision to take the leap. I feel fulfilled and challenged in a way that I never did in my previous job, and I know that I made the right choice for myself and my future.

When Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, I found myself faced with a difficult decision. I lived near the border, so I couldn't risk staying to see what would happen. I knew I had to make a quick decision and evacuate the country as soon as possible, for the safety of myself and my family.

This decision was not an easy one. I was leaving behind everything I had ever known, my home, my friends, my family. I felt very unsure about what would happen next. But I knew that I had to do whatever it takes to protect my children.

We hastily packed our bags and made our way to the train station, hoping to catch the last train out of the city. The scene at the station was chaotic - there were crowds of people pushing and shoving, everyone trying to board the same train. Children were crying, their parents trying to calm them down. People were shouting and screaming, desperate to get out of the city before it was too late. As we finally managed to board the train, I couldn't help but feel a sense of relief mixed with uncertainty and guilt. The train journey was long and uncomfortable, but we finally reached the border and crossed into a neighboring country. We were lucky enough to have some friends who took us in and helped us settle down.

As time passed, I realized that I had made the right decision. Several months after we left, our city was hit by a massive missile attack and our house was destroyed. Looking back on that difficult decision to flee the country, I am grateful for the safety and security we found in a new place. It wasn't an easy journey, but it was necessary to protect my kids and start a new life.

A few years ago, I was working as an accountant for a large corporation. At first, I was excited about the job, but after a few months, I started feeling like I was stuck in a rut. I was doing the same tasks every day, and there were no opportunities for me to grow professionally or be promoted within the company.

I tried talking to my supervisor about my concerns, but he didn't seem to take them seriously. He told me that I was doing a great job and that I should just keep doing what I was doing. But that didn't satisfy me. I felt like I was wasting my potential and my career was at a standstill.

I started looking for other job opportunities, but it was a difficult process. The job market in my field was competitive, and most of the available positions required several years of experience that I didn't have. However, I didn't give up. I continued to search and apply for jobs, and eventually, I received an offer from a smaller company.

Even though the new job had a lower salary than my previous position, it offered me the opportunity to take on more responsibility and grow professionally. I knew that it was a risk to leave a stable job for a new opportunity, but I decided to take the chance.

Quitting my old job was a difficult decision, and I was nervous about the future. But looking back, I know it was the right decision. The new company has given me the chance to learn new skills and take on more challenging projects. I feel more fulfilled in my career now and am excited about the opportunities for growth that lie ahead.

Several months ago it was the first time I had been caught in a real dilemma. I had to decide whether to study abroad or locally. Once my parents and I were having dinner, when suddenly they told me it was time to start thinking about my future and... (this is where the nightmare began) that they were ready to pay for my education abroad if it was what I really wanted to do. At first, I was on cloud nine, but then I started agonizing over the decision.

You can't even imagine how painful the process was. I asked my friends what they would do if they were given such an opportunity. Needless to say, opinions differed wildly. Then I made a list of pros and cons and analyzed all 'what-ifs' which threw me into doubt all the time. I also read a few articles about education abroad and found out what other students were saying about their experience. I even tried to consider job prospects in different countries.

I struggled to make a decision because my future was at stake. And, of course, I was afraid to suffer consequences of the wrong choice. It was difficult to imagine what living abroad would be like (taking into account the current situation regarding covid-19). Also, I knew I would have to start my life from the very beginning. And to top it off, I realised I would have to leave my friends and family behind.

After a great deal of thought I decided to seize this opportunity as it's better to regret what you have done than what you haven't. Now I'm planning to study in Canada. Of course, the outcomes cannot be accurately predicted yet, but I hope I made the right decision. We'll see. I'm still worried and fear disappointment but at the same time I'm looking forward to this change.

Every year before New Year's Eve, I write down my goals and wishes for the upcoming year. Since I absolutely love traveling, I always include a list of countries I'd like to visit. Like every year, I decided to write down a list of travel destinations.

I started surfing the internet, reading travel blogs, and watching videos on YouTube. One of the countries I came across was Cuba. I saw lots of pictures of its remarkable mountains, spectacular limestone hills, vast tobacco plantations, butter-soft beaches, lush green countryside, and colorful colonial cities. At some point, I realized there was something about Cuba that made me put it at the very top of my travel wish list.

Many travellers say that it's a truly unique place. The thing is, the country was isolated from the rest of the world for many years. And despite the fact that most restrictions were lifted some years ago, it hasn't changed a lot since then. Everyone says it seems to be lost in time, somewhere in the 1950's. I mean, people usually describe it as a place with salsa and rumba music playing everywhere, men smoking cigars and drinking rum, old American cars in the streets, and the beautiful colonial buildings with peeling paint in Old Havana. For me, it's really hard to believe that anything like that is possible in our modern world. So I want to experience it for myself.

At the moment, I don't know more than that, and I'm not planning to continue my research 'cause if I learn everything before visiting, there will be nothing left to discover when I go there one day. It won't be interesting. I know myself. So I really want to know more about this country, but I don't want to explore it from my couch.

When I was a child, I really wanted to have a dog. But my parents didn't seem to be charmed by the idea ‘cause when I said ‘dog', I imagined playing with my puppy, petting him, sleeping side by side at night, whereas my parents must have heard ‘time, expenses, a lot of extra work, and possible destruction of furniture and household goods'. So no matter how much I begged, they just kept saying ‘no'!

But I wanted to have a dog so desperately that I decided to go to extremes and promise my parents to take care of the dog and clean my room. So, one day, they said ‘yes'.

At first, I was really excited, so I did all my household tasks without being nagged to do so. I made my bed, cleaned my room almost every day, took out the trash, and did the dishes. I walked the dog twice a day, fed him, and cleaned up any accidents he had in the flat. But my excitement faded really quickly ‘cause I underestimated what this would take. I mean having a dog is like having a baby. You just can't wake up early to walk the dog one day, and then sleep in the next day. You have to walk the dog twice a day no matter how tired you are, and no matter what you're up to today. Day by day it was getting harder and harder to resist the temptation to do what I wanted to instead of what I promised to. So, my parents ended up taking care of the dog. And it was no longer MY dog, but it was our FAMILY dog. But I think they didn't mind.

answer.text:
Some time ago, I asked my elder sister what music she liked to listen to when she was my age. Soon, I regretted asking this question. Later, you'll understand why.

She played some of her favorite songs, and one of them was 'Wannabe' by the Spice Girls. I kind of liked it and decided to listen to it one more time. On the one hand, almost all the words were clear; however, I wasn't able to sing along. The only line I could sing along to was: "So tell me what you want, what you really, really want." To be honest, even now, I don't remember more than that.

Back then, I took it as a challenge. I found the lyrics and tried to read the first verse quickly. Then I attempted to sing along again. Although I could read the lyrics fast, I ran out of breath while trying to keep up with the vocalist. Every time, I ended up slurring my words like a drunk.

I decided not to give up. I told myself, 'Impossible is nothing.' I played the song over and over until I got tired of it. However, all my attempts to sing along with the first verse failed. Later, I realized I had made a fatal mistake by listening to that song on repeat.

The next day, I woke up with 'Wannabe' stuck in my head. I kept repeating those few lines from the verse over and over in my mind. I tried listening to other songs, but as soon as one song finished, 'Wannabe' would return, stuck on a loop in my head. I thought I was going to go crazy.

I must say, it's one of the most persistent earworms ever. Once it buries itself in your brain, it feels like you'd need surgery to remove it once and for all. Out of curiosity, I decided to google more about this girl group. What I found shocked me a little. This song is actually at the top of the list of the catchiest songs of all time. If only I had known that earlier.

Last Saturday, I was so excited because I planned to go to my friend’s birthday party. I even bought a new shirt for the occasion. I imagined how fun the party would be - music, food, and catching up with everyone.

But on Friday night, everything changed. I started feeling a bit strange. My throat felt scratchy, and I sneezed a few times, but I thought, ‘Oh, it’s nothing. I’ll be fine tomorrow.’

However, when I woke up on Saturday morning, I felt terrible. My head was heavy, my nose wouldn’t stop running, and I had a terrible cough. I checked my temperature, and it was higher than normal. I knew right away I couldn’t go to the party like this.

I felt so disappointed. I was really looking forward to seeing my friends, eating cake, and celebrating together. But I also didn’t want to ruin the party by coughing everywhere or making someone else sick. I texted my friend and told her I couldn’t come.

So instead of going out, I spent the day at home. I stayed in my pajamas, drank hot tea with honey, and watched a few old movies. My mom even made me some chicken soup, which was really comforting. Even though I missed the party, I knew it was the right decision to stay home and rest.

Well, last year I went to a winter resort, and I needed a big suitcase ‘cause I couldn't cram all my winter stuff into my small one. You know, just one sweater took up half the space. So I decided to borrow a bigger one ‘cause I didn't want to buy an item that I would use once in a blue moon. I have a friend from work who is a serial traveller, and he has suitcases of all sizes and shapes. So I decided to borrow a suitcase from him.

The one that he gave to me was hardside luggage. This made me a little worried. These suitcases are very stylish, but prone to cracking and damage. And they are particularly vulnerable to damage during carriage on an airplane while being loaded and unloaded. They do not like being thrown around as many baggage handlers do. I was really afraid it would be scratched or damaged in any other way.

What I feared came upon me. My luggage was damaged during the flight. I didn't know how to tell my friend about it. I decided to buy exactly the same suitcase and return it to my friend, hoping he wouldn't notice the change.

I spent a few days searching for it, but this suitcase model was out of stock. So all I could do was tell my friend the truth about his suitcase and offer a replacement item.

When I told him the news, he was so upset that he didn't even manage to get the right look on his face. It appeared to be his favourite suitcase. But he wasn't angry with me ‘cause it wasn't my fault.

I think that my best friend Ann is a rare example of a person who expresses her feelings freely. We've been friends for many years, and I see her almost every day. So I know what I'm talking about. I mean I have enough evidence to prove that she's an open person. Oh no, to say ‘open' is to say nothing. I think she's too open about her feelings.

If something is on her mind, she always lets people know about it whether they want it or not. For example, she tells people when something is bothering her, when something makes her feel excited, depressed or uncomfortable. She isn't afraid to tell people about painful or embarrassing situations that she experienced. And I know that she always says what she means, but not what other people want to hear. What's more, she posts a lot of personal details on Facebook and Instagram. I always joke that if we stopped being friends, I would still know as much information about her feelings and opinions as I do being her best friend and communicating with her every day.

On the one hand, I admire her ability to open up even to strangers ‘cause this helps her connect a lot more with other people. Her openness encourages other people to open up, and this helps to create a more open and trusting environment. Also, Ann is very easy to deal with, and it doesn't take much time to get to know her. When she is offended, she shows it and says that she's offended and explains why. When she's angry or embarrassed, she doesn't hide her emotions as well. Dealing with her doesn't require guesswork to understand what her opinion about something is, whether she's happy or not and why. You know, I find it really stressful and annoying to deal with people who have a blank and emotionless expression on their faces at all times. I can't read anyone's mind. And I don't want to.

On the other hand, I don't think it's good to be an open book all the time. I always tell her that she should be selective about who she tells about herself. First of all, it can be dangerous for her. And this makes her vulnerable. Also, I think she discloses too much too soon. This turns some people off. I'm sure it would be much better if she kept self-disclosure to conversations with close people. And it seems to me her being too open is the main reason why she's still single. This drives some guys away and makes them lose interest. And I have to say that her openness isn't always appropriate. I mean that by expressing what she is feeling, she not only passes some of her emotion to others, but she also has to be ready to deal with the aftermath of that disclosure. But she isn't.

One of the most important pieces of equipment in my home is a vacuum cleaner. I've been using it a lot since I decided to adopt a cat.

So, I had to promise to vacuum the floors, furniture, and carpets at least three times a week if I wanted to keep the kitten.

They even took pity on me and bought a vacuum cleaner specially designed for pet owners. It's a canister model, with the motor and dust collector connected to the vacuum head by a flexible hose. It’s a wheeled type and has really strong suction power, so cleaning doesn’t take much effort. It’s also compact and lightweight, making it easy to use.

I'm still keeping my promise, so I regularly vacuum all surfaces, using different attachments for different tasks. If it weren’t for this vacuum cleaner, the whole flat would be covered in cat hair because my tiny kitten grew into a very fluffy cat.

I’m really grateful that humanity invented this household device because it saves me a lot of time and lets me clean the whole flat quickly.

As far as TV series are concerned, my all-time favourite is the Game of Thrones, a TV drama series based on the epic fantasy novel series, A Song of Fire and Ice. It premiered in 2011, on HBO, but I watched it only last month. By the way, this was the first time I had watched an entire series in one sitting.

The events take place on the fictional continents of Westeros and Essos in a setting that very much resembles the Middle Ages. The main idea is that several noble families fight for control over the mythical lands of Westeros. These families are the Starks of Winterfell, the Lannisters of Casterly Rock, and the Baratheons of Dragonstone. To tell the truth, it's very difficult to say who the main character is as whenever one seems to be taking the lead, they are killed off.

What I really like is that this TV series has a really compelling plot, and I was always on the edge of my seat waiting to see what would happen next. Also, it's really thought-provoking and shows life as it is. First of all, it contains a lot of violent scenes, and this is what reminds me that our life is not a bed of roses, but a constant struggle. Secondly, it shows that there are countless ways to reach the same goal. All the heroes strive for the same thing, but use absolutely different strategies to achieve the desired result. Another thing that I like is that it is dynamic and not excessively long. There are just 10 episodes in each of the six seasons.

I'm sure this TV series is worth a few hours of your time if you haven't watched it yet.

Then, she put up posters with these eye-opening facts all around the office to encourage people to switch to electronic documents whenever possible and to think twice before printing anything. And it worked for us.

Beyond the office, she also helps protect the environment by organizing community cleanups in her neighborhood, and I know that many people support her efforts.

I really admire her because I think her contribution is invaluable. I wish there were more people like her. I mean people who understand that we shape society, so it’s up to us to make it better.

Some time ago, I watched a breathtaking live acro dance performance on TV. A friend of mine on Facebook sent me a message saying, 'Hurry up! Click the link! An incredible performance is about to start!' It was a live broadcast, so I decided to tune in, thinking I’d just take a short break from work.

At first, there were just two acro dancers moving gracefully across the stage. For the first 30 seconds, nothing extraordinary happened. I was hugely disappointed and was about to close the video when, suddenly, one of the girls did a handstand and landed in a bridge with one leg up. Her toes were perfectly pointed, and her leg was as straight as an arrow. And that’s when the magic began.

The other girl, the top partner, quickly mounted her and did a handstand on top of her foot. I gasped in amazement. You should have seen the judges. They were staring at the girls, open-mouthed. Then, the base girl started lifting her other leg up to about 45 degrees. I couldn’t believe my eyes. What I saw completely defied the laws of physics.

They kept going with more mind-blowing double tricks, insane partner handstands, and other gravity-defying acrobatic moves. One of the judges kept repeating, 'How is this even possible?' while the others watched in wide-eyed amazement. The performance was so incredible that I couldn't take my eyes off the stage. And I couldn’t help but watch it again and again. I was completely blown away.

To be honest, it's hard to put this experience into words - other than OMG, OMG, OMG! I was so impressed that I even posted about it on my Facebook timeline, which is something I almost never do.

In my country, one of the laws introduced in recent years is a smoking ban. It came into effect just a few years ago, which is pretty recent for a law.

I think this ban is one of the smartest laws ever passed. You know, if someone chooses to damage their health, that’s their right. I’m fine with that. But it's not fair for non-smokers to inhale tobacco smoke against their will just because smokers feel like lighting up wherever they please. So I’m happy that this ban keeps non-smokers away from secondhand smoke, which prevents a range of health issues like respiratory diseases, nausea, and headaches. It has also helped discourage smoking in general. Kids tend to copy what they see adults doing, so the less they see people smoking in public, the lower the chances they’ll pick up the habit themselves.

All in all, it’s a law that has done a lot of good. But I would take this law even further. I believe there should be stricter fines for littering cigarette butts, since many smokers still toss them on the ground without a second thought. Cigarette butts are non-biodegradable, and they pollute the soil, clog water systems, and leach dangerous chemicals into the environment. If the government really wants to tackle smoking-related problems, they should address this issue as well.

The only sport I enjoy watching, and sometimes even playing, is football. For this reason, of course, my favourite sports star is a football player. He is one of the greatest players of all time. Football experts compare him to the legendary Maradona. And I'm talking about Lionel Messi. He started making headlines many years ago, and he's still very popular.

Messi was born in a small town in Argentina. He was just 5 when he started playing football. When he was a teenager, agents from Barcelona saw his talent, and he moved to Spain. He became one of the youngest players in Barcelona. By the way, in 2021, he announced that he was leaving Barcelona after 21 years of playing for the club (the only club he had played for at that time) 'cause the club said it could no longer afford to pay. It was very emotional, and I even started crying when I saw him crying at his farewell press conference. After that, he played for Paris Saint-Germain for two seasons, and now he plays for Inter Miami in the USA.

He has had a lot of extraordinary achievements and won a lot of trophies so far. For example, in 2022, he won the World Cup with Argentina and was named the best player of the tournament. He also won multiple European Champions League titles and the World Club Championship with Barcelona. What's more, he's Argentina's all-time leading goalscorer.

I love to watch him playing, especially when he scores his beautiful goals from quick counterattacks. He is undoubtedly a natural talent. You know, the ball seems to be glued to his foot. He is a master at reading the game, and he's very quick. Everyone calls him the greatest dribbler of his generation. I particularly like when he dribbles at high speed, then he suddenly slows down, waits for the defender to get closer to him, then accelerates in the opposite direction. It doesn't matter how many defenders try to stop him, it's simply impossible. What's interesting is that everyone knows this trick, but he does it again and again, and defenders always go for that. answer.text:
I'm a total workaholic, so I almost never allow myself to step away from my endless to-do lists and take time for myself, even on weekends. But last Friday, I came home from work, collapsed on the sofa, and passed out. When I woke up on Saturday morning, I realized I needed a full day of doing nothing to reboot my system. I was on the verge of burnout. So, I decided to visit a spa center.

I went alone because I didn’t want to talk to anyone. If I had invited my friends, I would have had to engage in conversations, which would have drained all my energy. So, I kept my plan to myself.

I spent some time in a steam room, then moved to a sauna with dry herbal steam. I swam in a pool and even stepped into a snow room once. Between sauna sessions, I sipped herbal tea.

But what I enjoyed the most was the Japanese bath. There were two hot tubs (one at 45C and the other at 40C) plus a swimming pool with water at 6-8C. First, I sat in the hotter tub for about three minutes, then moved to the second one. After that, I plunged into the cold water before returning to the hot tub. I repeated this cycle several times. By the end, I felt like I was born again.

Some time ago, I told my husband that I was fed up with staying indoors almost all the time, both at work and at home. He promised that we would spend the whole day outside the following weekend. And we did.

My husband suggested going for a bike ride through the countryside. I agreed, even though I hadn’t ridden a bicycle since childhood. So, we rented two bikes, which didn’t cost much, and set off for our country house, which is in a beautiful area near a coniferous forest. Funnily enough, we had only ever had barbecue parties in the garden there and had never really explored the nature around us.

We took some food because we weren’t sure if we would be back quickly or spend the whole day cycling. We also brought a navigator to avoid getting lost in the middle of nowhere. At first, I rode at a snail’s pace, focusing entirely on balancing and steering. Of course, that meant I couldn’t really appreciate the scenery. But it was fun. It felt a bit like being a kid again.

Soon, I got the hang of it and started riding confidently. We passed cows grazing in green fields, ducks hiding in the grass, and beautiful wildflowers with butterflies fluttering around them. We often stopped to take photos and soak in the stunning views. Overall, it wasn’t a strenuous ride. Whenever we felt tired, we simply wheeled our bikes along.

By evening, we returned to our starting point and headed home. We were physically tired, but it helped me recharge my batteries, and it was fun.

If I could visit any place with a lot of trees, I would choose Central Park in New York. It’s one of the most famous parks in the world, and I’ve seen it so many times in American movies.

Every time I watch a film set in New York, there’s always a scene in Central Park. People are jogging, walking their dogs, or just relaxing on the grass. And then there are those bloggers who show off their amazing apartments with a view of the park. It looks so impressive.

The park is absolutely huge. When I see pictures of it from above, I can’t believe how big it is. A giant green space in the middle of a city full of skyscrapers. It’s crazy. I’m not an expert on trees, but I think there are a lot of oak, maple, and elm trees there. Some of them have massive trunks, which makes me think the park has been there forever. I can picture myself walking under those tall trees, with the leaves rustling in the wind. You know, it would feel like a little forest in the middle of the city.

Maybe when I finally get there, it won’t be as incredible as I imagine. But I still want to see it with my own eyes.

I don't mind people speaking on the phone in public places only when they have to discuss something that can't wait, and only if they do it quietly and briefly. And I can't stand when people start spilling personal information in the presence of complete strangers.

Several days ago this was just the case. I was standing in the checkout line at the supermarket. The line was long and slow-moving. So I decided to use this time to catch up on my emails. However, that wasn't going to happen ‘cause the woman behind me in line received a call.

She was having a long, loud, animated conversation on her cell phone. And she didn't care that a dozen people must have wanted to do what they were planning to. Instead, everyone learned that her mother had diabetes, her boss was cheating on his wife, and her sister was thinking of breaking up with her boyfriend. And she wasn't even afraid that the wrong third party could overhear the conversation.

I was really annoyed. It was an invasion of my personal space and peace of mind. If I could have predicted all that, I would have picked another line. But it was what it was. I was just standing there, hoping this nightmare wouldn't last forever.

Last year while I was on holiday in Greece, I decided to try oysters for the first time. I really wanted to taste them as there were so many people who loved them and the same number of people who hated them. So, on the one hand, I wanted to form my own opinion on this type of seafood. On the other, I was a bit afraid. The place we stayed in was right by the sea, so my friends persuaded me this was the best opportunity to duly appreciate the taste of oysters as they were supposed to be really fresh there.

We went to a seafood restaurant and ordered a large plate of oysters. Although they were expensive, I thought there wouldn't be a better chance in the near future, so I was determined to taste them come what may.

My friends started eating, saying every other second how delicious they were. I plucked up my courage, took the first oyster and slurped it before I changed my mind.

When my mouth was filled with slime, I had to swallow this slippery liquid just because there were many people around. But if I had been at home, I would have spitted it out immediately as the texture was just horrible.

A few minutes later I thought, okay, one more try. I grabbed another one, not expecting much, but somehow, it actually tasted good. Then I had a third. And before I knew it, I’d basically eaten the whole plate. Now, Now, anytime I get the chance, I order oysters without a second thought.

Since my last vacation I've had an overwhelming desire to try flyboarding. As the name suggests, it's like flying on water pressure. You stand on a board which is connected to a watercraft by means of a very long hose. The watercraft gives the flyboard propulsion, so you can move underwater and fly over the water.

First, I saw a video on Facebook which really impressed me. Then I was on holiday last summer and my friend suggested trying this activity.

Of course, I agreed without hesitation, but later understood that I wasn't a suitable candidate for this activity. So I refused. The main reason is that I didn't want to get injured and spend several months in hospital just because I wanted to jump out of water like a dolphin for 15 minutes. And at the time I wasn't fit enough. This meant I wouldn't be able to control my body and movements. I was afraid to damage my spine chord and break bones. However, my biggest fear was to have a heavy blow to the head. I saw that people fell down 100 times before they were able to flyboard properly. Also, it was quite expensive for me. It cost more than 100 dollars per 15 or 20 minutes. If I'd spent so much money, I would have spent the rest of my holiday dying of hunger.

So I refused, but my friend didn't. And It looked really impressive. On returning home, I decided to go to the gym regularly to get fitter and try flyboarding next time as it's absolutely different from all the activities I've done to date.

Now I'm looking forward to my next summer holidays as I'm sure it's a lot of fun flying above the water like Superman, let alone the thrill of getting the adrenaline pumping through my body. Also, I wonder whether I will be capable of mastering it and whether it's as difficult as it seems.

One of the best experiences I had ever had was participating in one of those ‘escape the room' games, you know, where a team of people is locked in a room and must find clues and solve puzzles to complete a given mission and find the key to escape. I had heard a lot about this type of entertainment and really wanted to participate, but only managed to when my friend decided to have an unusual birthday outing.

So, there were 6 or 7 of us in a team. We were kind of spies who broke into someone's house to find some secret files. Frankly speaking, I don't remember the storyline in detail, but I remember that we had one hour to escape the room to avoid being caught and imprisoned.

The room, in which we were locked, was packed with different stuff such as books, maps, fedoras, magnets, sticky notes, watches, old wigs, compasses, lamps, board games, playing cards. The puzzles were really challenging and intriguing.

It was real fun. We were frantically searching for clues. Some of them involved solving riddles, putting items in the correct order, or finding a set of objects hidden in the room. What I will never forget is that there was a broken clock and for a long time we couldn't figure out that we had to pay attention to the time it stopped on. By the way, it appeared to be the last clue. So we even thought we would sink with the ship, but then one us had a brainwave and we survived in the last minute.

It was really unusual an activity for all of us as we hadn't done anything like that before. And to tell the truth, I didn't expect it to be so interesting.

I've got a school friend, but we lost touch when we finished school. And I should say we used to be really good friends, that's why I regretted falling out of contact with him.

Recently I decided to call him and invite him to go somewhere so that we can catch up with each other. He seemed to be glad to hear me. So we arranged a meeting at the restaurant the next day at 6 pm.

Then on the day when we were supposed to meet, at the very last minute, he called me and said, 'Let's cancel, I can't make it. I have a fever and sore throat.' He said he had to stay in bed for a week or so. I said, 'It's ok. Get well soon'. You know, it's a normal situation. People get sick all the time.

But I had already booked a table, and it was too late to cancel a reservation. So I decided to go there anyway. When I came, I just froze, you know, 'cause I saw my friend talking to some girl. It looked like they had a date. And he obviously didn't look sick at all. What's more, he didn't look embarrassed. I was shocked. I just couldn't understand why he chose to lie to me and why he came to that very place.

A few weeks ago, I had lunch at a cafe with my friend. We hadn’t seen each other for a long time, and we were both in a hurry. But we decided to have a quick meeting to catch up.

Just when my friend was telling me something important, my phone started ringing. The number was unknown. On the one hand, I didn’t want to pick up the phone because I didn’t want to interrupt my friend. On the other hand, sometimes there can be emergencies when you need to call for help, and I thought it could be one of my friends or relatives. Sometimes, people might borrow someone else’s phone to make a call, so the number would be unknown.

But that wasn’t the case. It turned out to be a call from a bank. The bank worker asked if I wanted to get a credit card from them. I politely said I wasn’t interested, but she kept talking about the benefits of having one. The thing is, I’m too polite, and I find it hard to cut off people. If I were less polite, I would have ended the call in the very first minute. But the lady didn’t stop. She kept trying to keep me in the conversation, and I was getting more and more annoyed as I realized she was wasting our time. I should say I had a really hard time ending that call.

Plus, I hate talking on the phone in public places because I respect other people. When you talk to someone sitting in front of you, you can speak quietly, but when you talk on the phone, you speak louder, and that can disturb people around you.

Recently I was driving through the neighbourhood in which I lived when I grew up. And when I drove past the school, I immediately thought of my best childhood friend Alex. And he was not just my schoolmate but also my next door neighbour. So we used to spend a lot of time together. It was always fun ‘cause he always came up with something interesting. That's why we were never feeling bored. Also, I don't remember us having arguments frequently.

Then his family moved to a new neighbourhood. We were no longer neighbours, but we still studied together. Then we finished school, entered different universities, and lost touch.

When I drove past the school and remembered the good old times, I understood I really wanted to get back in touch with him. To be honest, I found it strange reaching out to him after so long. But I got up the courage and texted him. So, at first, I texted a simple ‘Hi'. Then I asked him if he was interested in getting together. He seemed to be interested in reconnecting, and we decided to catch up over coffee. On the one hand, I was looking forward to meeting him ‘cause it's always fun to remember the past. But I was a little worried that our friendship wouldn't be what it once was.

We met at a cafe. No words can really describe how happy I was to see him. First of all, I explained to him why it was that I fell out of touch. I think he appreciated knowing that it wasn't anything in particular that caused me to fall out of touch. Then we reminisced about the past. I was happy ‘cause I felt like I was reliving my carefree school days. And we promised to each other to keep in touch and arranged our next meetup.

Several years ago my best friend and I were on holiday in X country. Our tour guide recommended us to go to the city's traditional market, which is one of the oldest markets in X, always abuzz with local people and holidaymakers who go there to buy spices, fruit, clothing, souvenirs, handicrafts, fabrics, to name but a few. He told us that this would be a great way to get an interesting glimpse into local culture and do shopping.

Now I can safely say that it's by far the most crowded place I have ever visited. The market was teeming with people, it was just like a bee hive. Shoppers from all over the world were swarming around stalls so I had to squeeze through the crowd to get a closer look at anything that was sold. I couldn't even stop and look around as the crowd literally dragged me along. Vendors all vied in offering their goods to shoppers. It was really noisy.

I went their with my friend, whom I was travelling with, but no sooner had we reached the place than we were separated by the crowd. So we quickly understood that there was no point in trying to resist in order to keep together. I just tried to look around every other minute not to lose sight of her. For this reason, I can say I went there on my own.

Oh, and I nearly forgot one thing. I had to be very careful not to become pickpockets' victim because such crowded places are a paradise for them. Therefore, on the one hand, this experience was very interesting as the market's vibrant atmosphere made shopping lots of fun. But it was also a bit dangerous.

I recently saw The adjustment bureau and I was very pleased with the movie. Although this movie is not new, I hadn't even heard about it before and watched it by pure chance. I was at home, the weather was bad and I didn't want to go out, so I started flipping through the channels. I saw Matt Damon on the screen and decided to watch the film just because of him. I didn't regret, and I think this film was definitely worth a few hours of my time.

It is a romantic science fiction thriller that depicts an affair between a politician named David and a contemporary dancer, Elise. David accidentally meets Elise, while rehearsing his speech. After they kiss each other, he gets so inspired that he delivers a great speech that makes him a favourite in the election race. The only thing that makes him upset is that he doesn't even know the name of the girl. One month later they meet each other on a bus, but he doesn't manage to ask for her telephone number. Then he takes the same bus for three years to meet her, but some mysterious forces keep them apart. Later we find out that this is because all the events in people's lives are controlled by the Adjustment Bureau that ensures people live according to 'the Plan' because every time humanity is granted free will, it results in wars or other negative events. So the bureau tries to do whatever possible to stop them from meeting each other. One day David meets two men working for this bureau and they explain that they make corrections when things go slightly wrong. David is warned that if he doesn't stop making attempts to meet Elise, his memory will be erased. He decides to fight against it and tries to outsmart or elude the men in the suits and hats. To cut a long story short, in the end, the bureau issues a revised plan according to which Elise and David are meant to be together, and they are let go.

I really liked the movie, first of all, because I'm a huge fan of Matt Damon. Another great aspect of the film is that it raises the question and draws our attention to the dilemma of life, the conflict between free will and predestination. I love such inspirational movies that teach us to pursue our dreams and goals no matter what. I also liked the suspense of watching a good plot unfold. I'm not joking. I was on the edge of my seat waiting to see what would happen next. Overall, this movie is both entertaining and thought-provoking and it's definitely worth watching more than once.

And, of course, I want to discuss it with my friends because we are constantly debating whether our future is predetermined or whether people have free will. So it's just our favourite topic to talk about.

I live in a crowded high-rise building, and have neighbours next door, below and above. I guess, about a hundred people in total. So it's not surprising that most of them are nameless and faceless to me. The only person who stands out is my next-door neighbour.

This is an elderly man whose name is John. He's been living next door ever since I can remember. So I can say I've known him since my childhood.

John is retired now. And if I were him, I would sleep late, but he wakes up at 5 or 6 a.m. and always starts his day with morning exercises. He goes jogging, I think, every day regardless of the weather and the season. It's incredible. He's in his late 70s. I'm just 35, but I'm nowhere near as energetic as he is. I just can't help admiring him.

Another thing that draws people to him is that he will never say ‘no' if you ask him to water your flowers when you're away, keep an eye on your flat or feed your pets. I used to think he does it not to feel lonely, but some time ago I understood that this is just because he is a really caring and considerate person.

What's more, whatever happens, he looks on the bright side of life. Whenever I meet him, he is in a good mood with a big smile on his face. He never complains about his life although my parents told me that he'd got through lots of challenges. I wish there were more people like him.

The person that I can't help admiring and feeling deep respect to is my grandfather as he possesses qualities that are in short supply nowadays.

First of all, just imagine, now my grandfather is in his late 80s, but he seems to be more energetic than most of my peers. Being retired, he could sleep late, but he wakes up at 5 or 6 a.m., always starting his day with morning exercises. Then he does different chores, like washing and cleaning. You know, he's been doing all housework himself since my grandmother died. Also, he works in the yard, in the orchard, and in the vegetable garden. Yet, he never feels tired. At least, he never says he's tired. It's incredible. I'm just 35, but I'm nowhere near as active as him.

There's one more thing that makes me admire him. He reads a lot every day, so it seems to me there aren't topics that wouldn't be interesting for him.

What's more, whatever happens, he looks on the bright side of life. And he has always taught me to have a positive attitude to events and people. I know that he got through a lot of challenges, but he never complains. On the contrary, he always emphasises that if it hadn't been for those hardships and if he hadn't had to work hard, he wouldn't have achieved anything in life.

Also, he is the first person I rush to when I have some dilemma. He has always given me sound advice. Somehow he manages to come up with brilliant solutions to all problems we discuss.

Sometimes we just watch TV programs together, drinking tea and reminiscing about the past. I really wish there more people like my grandfather.

Just recently I saved my uncle from a rash decision. We had a small family gathering last Friday evening, and I noticed that he was acting aggressively and losing his temper at the smallest thing. I asked him what happened, and he said he was thinking of quitting his job.

Of course, it was obvious that this decision would impact his life significantly. So I decided to interfere, but I didn't want to put too much pressure on him, so I just said something like 'I'm here for you if you ever want to talk'.

Just as I expected it appeared that he decided to quit his job 'cause he had a conflict with a colleague. So I realised that his decision was emotional, not logical. Moreover, this meant he wanted to quit a job without another one lined up, which entails uncertainty and having no income for an indefinite period of time. So I decided to help my uncle 'cause I'm convinced that this is what family is for. And I think it's natural to want to make someone you love and care for feel better again.

I didn't tell him that he needed to calm down. Instead, I just listened to him and let him vent. About an hour later he realised he was blowing things out of proportion and that he just needed to talk to his colleague face-to-face before the conflict got out of hand.

I have a friend who is incredibly opinionated. To her, there are only two opinions: hers and the wrong one. You know, she often says ‘It’s my way or the highway’. We've been friends since childhood, so I've grown used to this part of her personality and don't pay much attention to it anymore. But other people can't stand being around her for long.

She believes she knows best how everyone should behave and constantly offers unsolicited advice, which is really annoying to many. But what really pushes people away is that she doesn’t like listening to ideas that are different from their own. If someone disagrees with her, she says they don’t understand what they are talking about. This often makes people feel stupid after talking to her, and those who know her well just try to avoid her. So it's not surprising that she has few friends. But overall, she's a good person. If it weren't for her being so opinionated, she would definitely have many more friends.

The only time I think being opinionated helps her is in running her Instagram blog. She doesn't care about haters at all and considers them fools. I wish I could react like that to the criticism and nasty comments I receive from time to time.

Last year I came to realize that the quality of my life would improve significantly if I started leading a healthy lifestyle. What I did first was I read a lot of articles in magazines and consulted a dietician because without professional help diets may do more harm than good. The biggest challenge was to stop eating fast food. I started to choose carefully what I ate, when and what for. I became a frequent visitor of a gym and did exercises regularly. At least 3 times per week.

I've been living like this for more than a year now. I have to confess that this appeared to be more difficult than I expected as, first of all, this requires discipline and time. For example, sometimes you don't want to go to the gym. You say to yourself that nothing will happen if you skip one workout. But you understand that if you do it once, nothing will prevent you from doing it regularly. Secondly, when you eat fast food, you don't have to think at all. You take whatever you see in a shop just to make your stomach full. But if you start eating healthy food, you think about its nutritional value, you count calories and try to choose fresh high-quality meat, fruit and vegetables.

In any case, all these efforts are worth changing the way you live. For instance, it was not until I started following a healthy diet and doing sport regularly that I began to lose weight naturally without starving myself. As a result, I started looking slimmer and feeling better. What's more, I became much more attractive for the opposite sex. Now I have many admirers who say that I'm beautiful, and my photos get really many likes in social networks. My health has improved significantly since I started taking the first steps towards changing my life. I have started feeling more energetic than before. This has also helped me get better skin, so now I don't look as pale as before. To sum up, the quality of my life has improved dramatically.

Last year, our company decided to start using CRM software because my boss finally realized that in the age of big data the company had to move beyond the sticky notes, EXCEL spreadsheets and disorganized filing cabinets, and start using advanced organizational technology that can track sales, locate trends, automate many of the interactions that occur in the company on a daily basis and, what’s important, make that data available across departments.

But the company is not so big, and therefore it doesn't have a dedicated technical support department. So we had to make a software implementation plan ourselves. Five of us teamed up to work on this project. And my boss asked me to take the lead on it.

At first, we wanted to find the right CRM solution for our company's needs. I made a list of CRM vendors, and each team member had to evaluate at least one CRM system. Then we all worked together to plan and manage the implementation schedule, provide employee training, and ensure a smooth transition for our employees.

As a team lead, I was responsible for making sure team members were productive, the project remained within budget, and deadlines were met. Also, I had to organize training sessions, weekly webinars, and blog posts that all employees of our company could access if and when they needed help or guidance.

It wasn't as easy as I thought it would be. First of all, I had a hard time motivating people to work overtime because we couldn't ignore our everyday work duties. Plus, I faced resistance from many employees in our company 'cause their first thought was that the new software would be too difficult to learn, or it would disrupt their comfort levels, or even replace their jobs. But I was immensely proud because my boss entrusted me with such a critical task, and I successfully handled it despite having no prior experience.

I'm a person who's forever losing something. And in most cases, I don't notice that some item is missing for a long time… if ever… However, recently there was one case that I remember very well. This is because I lost my phone, and it was a total disaster because I am not ashamed to say that I can't survive even an hour without the device. It's like my best friend.

So, one day I returned home after a busy day and wanted to text one of my friends, but I couldn't find my phone. At first, I didn't worry at all. I asked my mom to call my phone ‘cause I was sure it was somewhere in my purse or in one of the pockets. What we heard was ‘the phone you dialled is not available at the moment'. This meant that locating my phone fast and easily was out of question. I thought the battery had gone flat, therefore it would just take a little more time to find it. I searched high and low, but the search was without success. I realized I'd lost it.

At that very moment I felt like my heart was coming to a complete stop. I started panicking. I thought that someone would hack my phone password and get access to my photos and notes, my accounts on social media, which was the last thing I wanted to have happened. I thought of the potential consequences of my being out of contact for what might be several days. Among other things, it was an expensive item, and I'd been saving for a long time to afford it.

The worst thing about it was that I had no idea where I lost it. I found out there was a hole in my pocket that I didn't realize was there. So this might have happened in a taxi. Or I may have left it in a changing room in the department store. The only thing I remember was that I called my friend after I left the office. This means I didn't leave it in the workplace. But I wished I had. I was upset and frustrated. And I was really angry about the whole thing. But anyway, I never saw my phone again.

In my country, there are a lot of reasons to celebrate. And there are lots of dishes that people cook to offer their guests something delicious to eat. But whatever the occasion, there's one dish that you'll always see on a festive table. The dish I'm talking about is roast chicken. And the main reason why it's so popular is that it's always a safe bet. First of all, I've never met people who have allergy to chicken. Also, it's very easy to cook. And it doesn't take much time. Another reason is that it's really hard to find someone who doesn't like its taste.

So, it's a very simple dish, yet really tasty. I mean it's tasty even if you just season it with salt and black pepper, rub a little oil all over the chicken skin, and cook until golden. But for special occasions, people try to make it a little more sophisticated and add garlic, herbs or sauces.

I particularly like roast chicken thighs because they have crispy skin, and because they are juicy, especially when they are marinated. What I usually do is carefully part the skin from the meat of the chicken and stuff the gap with fresh, delicate herbs such as parsley, basil and marjoram. Then I tie it up and roast it with some olive oil and salt. I cook until it is crispy and cooked through.

So recipes may differ a little, but the result is the same: tender meat with crispy skin. It is always so good that it practically melts in the mouth.

People who have pets know very well how important it is to have a very good vet because, unlike people, animals cannot tell you what is wrong, how long they have been feeling pain, how intense their pain is. Animals cannot verbally communicate their pain. So, having a professional who can make an accurate diagnosis of your pet's condition and provide effective treatment recommendations is a real blessing because the same symptoms could be caused by many different infections and diseases.

I'm lucky to know an expert whom I can fully trust and count on. Moreover, I recommend this vet to others without being afraid that some people will have negative experience dealing with her. Her name's Helen. And she's considered one of the luminaries of veterinary medicine. I know that many other acknowledged specialists in the field respect her and often ask for advice. And that's saying a lot, to my mind.

She is so good at her job that people come to her veterinary clinic from all over the country even though they sometimes have to travel very long distances several times a week or month to have an appointment with her. She has patients in other countries too. She is able to make an accurate diagnosis even without seeing an animal. All you need is to give her the results of all the tests she has asked for.

It may sound implausible, but she can work miracles. She treats animals when other vets throw up their hands in despair and either say they don't know what to do or it's too late to do something. And she doesn't give up if there's even the slightest chance to rescue an animal.

She is a really dedicated professional. If there is an emergency, she will help you no matter where she is and what she does. You can contact her after midnight, and she won't sleep the whole night if life of your pet is at stake.

My grandfather was a doctor. He had been working at a regional hospital for more than 50 years. He started his career as a doctor's assistant. And then he worked as a doctor for many years. He examined, diagnosed and treated patients. He literally worked day and night. I think it was hard. Very hard. But I'm sure that he did exactly what he was born to do, and he wouldn't have changed his job for all the world. For him, it wasn't just a job, it was his calling.

My grandfather's work occupied all his time. He never had a second job. It was just impossible as he had no time for that. If he had had a second job, he would have died of fatigue. Sometimes I doubted my grandfather was a human being. He didn't have hobbies. He didn't meet friends. He even missed most family gatherings. You know, it's not fun at all. He was always tired, and his eyes were always red because of endless sleepless nights. When he wasn't on duty, he was reading different books and reviewing medical records of his patients.

In my opinion, it is a very rewarding job. But I wouldn't like to do anything like that because it's really stressful, especially when you understand that you cannot help some patient. Also, doing shift work is not my cup of tea. I can't imagine myself working night shifts. What's more, I don't want to sacrifice everything for work.

I remember that several years ago I went to a zoo while travelling abroad. And it was then when I saw a real live wild animal for the first time. Probably, I went to zoos in my childhood. I'm sure I did, but I don't have reliable memories about that experience.

I thought I would be excited, but when I saw a white tiger I was upset and disappointed. This poor animal was kept in a cramped space without access to natural light. When I saw it, it was lying on the concrete floor in a kind of trance as if it was waiting to die. I think it's cruel to confine a big carnivore to a tiny, dark, artificial, unenriched enclosure where it never sees any daylight . I was really sorry for that poor tiger that didn't even have a chance to seek privacy from the public and didn't have an opportunity to take part in natural behavior such as running, jumping or climbing. Also, I was a bit terrified. I was afraid the animal would somehow escape from the cage and bite me to death. On the one hand, I knew the cage was strong enough so this was an unlikely occurrence, but there are always ‘what ifs' in the mind, which make you feel nervous seeing a big wild animal not far from you.

So, this was one of the most unpleasant experiences in my life, and I really hope I won't have to go to a zoo in the future.

Recently I've had an experience of what I consider to be exceptional rather than just good customer service. I wanted to buy a new laptop. First, I wanted to find a suitable one online, but I was overwhelmed by the number of options available. In the end, I decided to go to a reputable electronics store as it was too expensive a purchase for me to throw money away and buy the first thing I saw online.

When I entered the store, one of the sales assistants greeted me. He waited for some time to let me look around, then approached me only after I made eye contact with him, showing I needed his assistance. The guy introduced himself and started asking me a lot of questions to find out what exactly I needed. While listening, he didn't interrupt me, he listened to me really carefully and did want to find the right solution for my individual needs not just sell me something because that something would pay him more. Also, he was knowledgeable about the product and very patient. If I'd been him, I would have killed me as I asked a dozen silly questions, and some of them more than once. Unfortunately, the laptop I'd chosen appeared to be out of stock, so he offered to contact other branches to find the model I wanted. Again, he didn't try to sell something what I didn't need. That is where I would say normal service ends. Of course, I agreed to wait a bit.

It took him about a week to find the laptop I wanted, but, in the meantime, he phoned me a couple of times to let me know how it was going. I think it it the intermediate phone calls that made this exceptional. He let me know that he hadn't forgotten about me. It may not sound like much, but it really made me feel valued as a customer. In my opinion, he went beyond what the company would require or expect to find a positive solution and to provide me with good service. And I really appreciated that.

When I started high school, my parents began expecting me to make a decision about my future career. But I didn’t know what career path to follow because there were so many options to choose from, and I was afraid I might make the wrong choice and suffer the consequences for the rest of my life.

At some point I realised that I could no longer delay making a decision, so I decided to ask my father for advice about my career choice because he had always given me good suggestions about everything.

My father told me that if I wanted to have a great career, I had to pursue my passion or I would end up feeling bored and unfulfilled otherwise. Actually, this was what everybody said. I mean I knew that. But I didn’t know how to find my passion.

To be honest, visiting cultural places like museums isn't really my thing because I'm not interested in learning about culture. But if I were, I'd go to our local Historical Museum.

I haven't been there myself. I just often walk past the building when I'm in the city center. It's a big, old building. It has tall windows and a large wooden door at the front. It's hard not to notice it when you walk by because it contrasts with the modern buildings around it. It really stands out. But those who have been there say it's quite interesting.

I imagine the Historical Museum might have a section where they showcase old tools and household items. There could be antique sewing machines, old-fashioned lamps, and even historical toys that children used to play with. Also, I think the museum might feature a display of traditional clothing from different periods. They could have old dresses, suits, and accessories that show how fashion has evolved over time. It might include a room with vintage agricultural equipment, like old plows and farming tools to help visitors understand how farming practices have changed throughout history. I suppose there might be an exhibit on old transportation methods too. They could have models of early cars, horse-drawn carriages, and even antique bicycles to show how people got around in the past… And various other exhibits that demonstrate how our society's culture has evolved over time, including changes in technology, daily life, and social customs…

What I know for sure is that the museum also teaches visitors about how these past lifestyles contributed to shaping our nation's culture. As I mentioned before, I often walk past it and see announcements about special events. For example, last month, they had a ‘History Day’ where children could dress up in old-fashioned clothes and learn how to make simple toys from the past. My friend went and said it was a lot of fun. Even though I’m not very interested in museums, it does sound like a good time.
